  • State: AL

  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 17, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1263 was damaged by a forklift and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hepaco to remediate the impacted surfaces. Hepaco personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted interior and swept them in utilizing hand tools. The crew then containerized all UN1263 impacted material in one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 85-gallon overpack for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023050674
item.description:
Report E-2023050674

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-19T18:11:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-30
  • City: MONTGOMERY
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 30, 2023, at 1429 hours, FRA Hazmat inspector Kevin Cash reported GATX 37155, a loaded tank car of Creosote located in the CSX Montgomery Yard, was leaking from the manway. The car was isolated and the shipper, Blackwater Midstream, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2023-05-30-00318). Marion Environmental Inc. (MEI), a CSXT response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found two of the six manway cover bolts were less than tool tight and the manway cover gasket was significantly worn. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative- Blake Chatagnier (504-414-2040, bchatagnier@bwcterminals.com). Contractor personnel replaced the manway cover gasket, properly secured all manway cover bolts, and wiped away residual product that was adhering to the outside of the car. Upon completion the car released for transport.

item.description:
Report E-2023040601

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-19T18:11:52+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-11
  • City: BESSEMER
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics Terminal NBM experienced a UN1814 "pH Up" release from a 6-gallon poly jug. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately all 6-gallons of product released to a 35' x 9' area of the trailer floor and a 12' x 20' area of the asphalt lot below due to being crushed. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. Spill King was utilized to neutralize the impacted areas. Impacted freight was wiped down. The damaged jug, impacted absorbents and pads were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 1523 ET, XPO Logistics terminal NBM contacted ERTS to report a spill that occurred inside of a trailer in Bessemer, AL. The spill consisted of a 55-gallon metal drum of NA1993 Glycol Ether EB, which was found emptied out prior to arrival due to a puncture at the bottom of the drum which caused the liquid to spill out of the drum and out of the side of the trailer during transit. The terminal stated the drum was empty and needed an 85-gallon overpack metal drum dropped off so they could dispose of it. ERTS scheduled a contractor to drop an 85-gallon metal drum to the terminal Contractors did not report seeing any release of product upon arrival to the terminal.

  • Description: On April 4, 2023, at 1730 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Ranger personnel in Falkville, Alabama regarding the release of approximately 1 quart of Neutrachill (Sodium hydroxide solution, UN1824 8, II). item.title: Report I-2023030008
item.description:
Report I-2023030008

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-18T21:08:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-02-14
  • City: TUSCALOOSA
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ALABAMA SOUTHERN RAILROAD LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While switching in the Tuscaloosa Yard, an ABSR Conductor discovered a tank car (WCHX 29244) in an inbound cut of CSX bridge traffic destined for the KCS. The car appeared to have a substance that had sloshed from the top in route to the ABS from CSX. It was a minimal amount (appeared less than a gallon) that was only on the top and streaked down the side of the car, and it was not actively leaking when he discovered it. He said the splatter marks are what alarmed him. He immediately stopped all movement, backed away, and contacted Trainmaster. The conductor gave the trainmaster the UN designation, and it was discovered that the car was loaded will Class 3 Flammable Petroleum Distillates (UN 1268). The Trainmaster and Mr. Flagg followed the guidelines listed in the ERG and stayed a Safe Distance away from the car, making sure there were no ignition sources in the area. After determining that car was not actively leaking, the team contacted myself and Josh Jewell, railcar repair supervisor. Josh Jewell found that the manway gasket was defective, allowing the liquid to escape when the car was being moved by the CSX. The car was carefully located to a safe location in the Tuscaloosa Yard and the car owner has been contacted to provide their preferred mobile tank car repair company to make the appropriate repairs for safe travel of the car to final destination.

  • Description: On December 19, 2022 at 1556 ET, XPO Logistics (NBM terminal) contacted ERTS regarding a UN3082, Environmentally hazardous Substance, Liquid, N.O.S. (Diethylmethylbenzenediamine), 9, PG III "OR93SLM" release that was discovered at 1430 ET. It was advised that up to 55 gallons of product released to the trailer floor and lot from at least (1) 55-gallon steel drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup and containment of the material. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately all 55-gallons of product released to an 8' x 10' area of the trailer floor and the asphalt lot below due to a puncture. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon metal drum. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted areas and collected. The impacted absorbents, contaminated pallet, and all other cleanup debris were containerized into six 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Terminal NBM called in to report a 30-gallon spill of UN1263 "DuraCoat" from a 55-gallon metal drum caused by a forklift puncture and impacting their trailer floor. The spill was ongoing and contained to the trailer floor. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 30-gallons of product released to the trailer floor in a 10' x 12' area and to the concrete lot in a 2' x 2' area due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was collected into a 95-gallon poly drum. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area and then containerized into three 55-gallon poly drums. MEG personnel utilized absorbents and hand tools to remediate the impacted surface, then containerized all paint thinner-impacted material and the damaged pail in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

Report E-2023010140

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-18T21:08:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2022-09-21
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 21, 2022, ERTS was contacted by Landstar regarding the release of approximately 10 gallons of Formaldehyde solution (Formaldehyde Solution, UN2209) from (1) 50-gallon plastic drum. The release was reportedly due to a forklift puncture. ERTS then dispatched contractors to clean up the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed the cause and amount of the release. Affected media and trailer flooring components were subsequently addressed via absorbents and/or pressure washing activities, while simultaneously collecting rinse-water. Spent absorbents and all other waste material generated were containerized in (2) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste drums were then transported by contractors to Clean Earth in Glencoe, Alabama for proper disposal.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was processed the day before the incident and was loaded on a trailer. When unloaded the following morning and took to the belt the package then was loaded the truck and the put on the top shelf and on it side this is when it started to leak. It was then discovered that the package was leaking on the truck. It was then put in a bag and then a tote and transported to the Hazmat Cage where the Hazmat team was notified of it. DescribePack: The package was inadequately handled and loaded by a package handler and the bucket inside started to leak. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Upon the discovery that it was leaking the package handler notified the manager who put it in a bag and a tote to have the package not spill its contents anymore

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package was not recognized as a Hazmat by the package handlers and sent up the belt. When it made it to the splitters it was found that the box was a hazmat and was leaking. The package was then placed in a tote and sent down the chute to QA. QA saw it was a hazmat and that it was leaking. They notified managers, QA, and the hazmat team of the package and its spill. DescribePack: The box was dropped and the cans were crushed and the tops popped off. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was put in a tote and put in a bag and Hazmat team was notified upon arrival to terminal.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2022-07-05
  • City: BIRMINGHAM
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDEX GROUND PACKAGE SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver claims to have reported at around 9 AM that they had a damaged package on van while on route because they could smell paint fumes. Driver was told to finish their route and bring it to the station afterwards. Driver was didn't know which package it was until they were to deliver hazmat back to shipper. Did not get to the station until around 6 PM. Paint that spilled was dried in the back corner of van. DescribePack: Two of the four paint buckets had their tops popped off and the sides of the buckets were slightly bent. package was possibly dropped. DurationRel: 8 and MitigateEffect: driver seemed to have isolated the package in a corner in back of van once they realized it was leaking or as they were about to deliver package back to shipper. Amphomag was spread on dry paint in back of van to try and eliminate fumes.
